title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:2, who shall judge the world?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:2 states that the saints shall judge the world.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6:3 say we shall judge?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:3 clearly says that we shall judge angels.

questions.question: Who does Paul say should judge matters pertaining to this life, according to 1 Corinthians 6:4?
options: Those least esteemed in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Those least esteemed in the church
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:4 advises to set those least esteemed in the church to judge matters of this life.

questions.question: What is Paul’s reaction to believers going to law one against another, according to 1 Corinthians 6:7?
options: There is utterly a fault among you
questions.correctAnswer: There is utterly a fault among you
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:7 states that there is utterly a fault among the believers because they go to law one with another.

questions.question: Which of these groups is NOT listed in 1 Corinthians 6:9 as unrighteous who shall not inherit the kingdom of God?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:9 lists many unrighteous groups but does not mention prophets.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6:11 say about some believers’ past?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:11 acknowledges that some believers were once unrighteous but are now washed and sanctified.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:12, what does Paul say about things lawful for him?
options: All things are lawful but not all things are expedient
Only a few things are lawful
questions.correctAnswer: All things are lawful but not all things are expedient
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:12 states that all things are lawful but not all are expedient or beneficial.

questions.question: What is the body NOT for, according to 1 Corinthians 6:13?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:13 says the body is not for fornication but for the Lord.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:15, what are your bodies described as?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:15 states that your bodies are members of Christ.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6:18 instruct believers to do?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:18 commands believers to flee fornication.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 6:1 encourages believers to take their disputes before unbelievers.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:1 questions if anyone dares to go to law before the unjust instead of before the saints, implying believers should not take disputes before unbelievers.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 6:20 states that believers are bought with a price.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:20 clearly says believers are bought with a price and should glorify God.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 6:17 says he that is joined unto the Lord is one body.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:17 states that he that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit, not one body.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Corinthians 6:19: 'What? know ye not that your body is the temple of the ______ which is in you...?'
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:19 states that your body is the temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:16, what happens when a man is joined to an harlot?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:16 teaches that he which is joined to an harlot is one body, for two shall be one flesh.

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with conflict in the church and is considering suing another brother in a secular court. Based on 1 Corinthians 6, what biblical principle should you share about resolving disputes?
options: Believers should settle disputes among themselves rather than before unbelievers
It is acceptable to sue fellow believers in secular courts
Disputes should be ignored to keep peace
Only church elders have authority to judge disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should settle disputes among themselves rather than before unbelievers
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:1-6 teaches that believers should not bring lawsuits before unjust or secular courts but rather resolve matters among the saints. This preserves the witness of the church and honors God.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 6 encourage believers to view judgment within the church?
options: Saints are called to judge even angels and the world
Judgment is reserved only for God
Only pastors can judge matters in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Saints are called to judge even angels and the world
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 affirm that believers will judge the world and even angels, indicating their responsibility to judge smaller matters within the church wisely and righteously.

questions.question: What attitude does Paul rebuke in believers who take their disputes to secular courts, according to 1 Corinthians 6?
options: Pride and lack of wisdom among the saints
questions.correctAnswer: Pride and lack of wisdom among the saints
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 6 show Paul's shame that there is not a wise man among them to judge between brethren, rebuking the pride and lack of wisdom that leads them to go before unbelievers.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6, how should believers respond when wronged by a brother instead of suing?
options: Take the wrong patiently and suffer defrauding
Immediately seek restitution through legal means
Cut off fellowship with the offender
questions.correctAnswer: Take the wrong patiently and suffer defrauding
questions.explanation: In verse 7, Paul suggests it is better to suffer wrong or be defrauded than to go to law against a brother, promoting humility and peace within the church.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6 say about the inheritance of the kingdom of God in relation to unrighteous behavior?
options: The unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God
All are forgiven regardless of behavior
Only sins against others prevent inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: The unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Verses 9 and 10 list various unrighteous behaviors and warn that those who practice them will not inherit God's kingdom, emphasizing holiness and obedience.

questions.question: A believer struggling with past sins asks about their standing before God. What biblical truth does 1 Corinthians 6 offer?
options: Some were once sinners but are now washed and sanctified through Jesus and the Spirit
Sins must be confessed publicly to be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: Some were once sinners but are now washed and sanctified through Jesus and the Spirit
questions.explanation: Verse 11 reminds believers that although some were once sinners, they are now washed, sanctified, and justified by the Lord Jesus and the Spirit of God.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 6 address Christian freedom in relation to self-control?
options: All things are lawful but not all things are expedient
Christians can do anything without consequences
Freedom means doing whatever feels right
Self-control is not necessary for believers
questions.correctAnswer: All things are lawful but not all things are expedient
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches that while believers may have freedom, they must exercise wisdom and avoid being mastered by anything, promoting disciplined living.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6 say about the purpose of the body in relation to sin?
options: The body is not for fornication but for the Lord
The body is free to indulge in any desire
The body is irrelevant to spiritual life
Sinful acts do not affect the body
questions.correctAnswer: The body is not for fornication but for the Lord
questions.explanation: Verse 13 explains that the body is created for the Lord and not for sexual immorality, encouraging believers to honor God with their bodies.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6, what is the relationship between a believer's body and Christ?
options: Believers' bodies are members of Christ
The body is separate from Christ
Christ only indwells the spirit, not the body
Believers' bodies belong to themselves alone
questions.correctAnswer: Believers' bodies are members of Christ
questions.explanation: Verse 15 teaches that believers’ bodies are members of Christ, so joining the body to sin is forbidden as it dishonors Christ.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 6 describe the union between a believer and the Lord in contrast to the union with an immoral person?
options: Joined to the Lord is one spirit; joined to a harlot is one flesh
Union with the Lord is physical
Union with others is spiritual only
questions.correctAnswer: Joined to the Lord is one spirit; joined to a harlot is one flesh
questions.explanation: Verses 16 and 17 contrast the one-flesh union with a harlot to the one-spirit union with the Lord, highlighting the spiritual nature of the believer’s relationship with Christ.

questions.question: What practical advice does 1 Corinthians 6 offer for overcoming temptation related to sexual sin?
options: Flee fornication to avoid sinning against your own body
Ignore temptation as it will pass
questions.correctAnswer: Flee fornication to avoid sinning against your own body
questions.explanation: Verse 18 instructs believers to flee sexual immorality because it is a sin against their own body, emphasizing avoidance as a practical means of holiness.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 6 teach about the believer's body in relation to the Holy Spirit?
options: The body is the temple of the Holy Ghost dwelling within
The body is unimportant to the Spirit
The Holy Spirit only dwells in the soul
The body is sinful and separate from the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The body is the temple of the Holy Ghost dwelling within
questions.explanation: Verse 19 emphasizes that believers' bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, urging them to honor God by caring for their bodies.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "For ye are bought with a price: therefore __________ God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God's."
questions.explanation: Verse 20 commands believers to glorify God in body and spirit because they were bought with a price, emphasizing reverence and worship in daily living.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 6, it is acceptable for believers to let disputes with brothers be judged by unbelievers.
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 6 instruct believers not to bring disputes before unbelievers but to judge matters within the church, maintaining Christian witness.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 6 teaches that Christians have freedom to do all things, but they should not be mastered by anything.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that all things are lawful but not all are expedient, and believers should not be brought under the power of anything, affirming responsible freedom.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:1, where does Paul admonish believers to bring their disputes instead of before the unjust?
options: Before the elders of the synagogue
questions.explanation: Paul instructs believers to settle disputes among themselves, i.e., before the saints, rather than taking matters before unjust secular courts (1 Corinthians 6:1).

questions.question: What future role of the saints is cited in 1 Corinthians 6:2 to argue their capability to judge?
questions.explanation: Paul reminds the Corinthians that the saints will judge the world, validating their ability to judge even the smallest matters (1 Corinthians 6:2).

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 6:3, Paul claims believers will judge angels. What type of Greek term does this reflect emphasizing believers' authority?
questions.explanation: Paul uses typology here by drawing a parallel between believers' spiritual authority and eschatological judgment roles, emphasizing their elevated status (1 Corinthians 6:3).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:4, who should be appointed to judge matters pertaining to this life?
options: Those least esteemed in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Those least esteemed in the church
questions.explanation: Paul suggests that even those least esteemed in the church can be appointed to judge worldly matters, highlighting the spiritual maturity expected (1 Corinthians 6:4).

questions.question: What is Paul's tone in 1 Corinthians 6:5 when he asks if there is not a wise man among the believers?
questions.explanation: Paul expresses shame and rebuke, highlighting the failure of believers to resolve disputes wisely (1 Corinthians 6:5).

questions.question: Which practice among believers does Paul criticize in 1 Corinthians 6:6 as bringing disputes before unbelievers?
options: Going to law against one another
questions.correctAnswer: Going to law against one another
questions.explanation: Paul condemns the practice of believers suing each other before unbelievers, which damages the church’s witness (1 Corinthians 6:6).

questions.question: What alternative does Paul suggest in 1 Corinthians 6:7 instead of taking legal action against a brother?
questions.explanation: Paul urges believers to accept wrong or defraud themselves rather than damage the unity of the church through litigation (1 Corinthians 6:7).

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 6:9-10, which of the following is NOT listed among those who will not inherit the kingdom of God?
questions.explanation: Prophets are not mentioned in the list of unrighteous who will not inherit the kingdom, unlike fornicators, covetous, and drunkards (1 Corinthians 6:9-10).

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 6:11 describe the transformation of some believers formerly involved in unrighteous behavior?
questions.explanation: Paul affirms believers’ transformation through cleansing, sanctification, and justification in Jesus’ name and by the Spirit (1 Corinthians 6:11).

questions.question: What principle does Paul articulate in 1 Corinthians 6:12 regarding freedom and self-control?
options: All things are lawful but not all things are expedient
All things are forbidden except what is commanded
Freedom is absolute and without restraint
questions.correctAnswer: All things are lawful but not all things are expedient
questions.explanation: Paul teaches that while believers have freedom, not all actions are beneficial or should control them (1 Corinthians 6:12).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:13, what is the ultimate destiny of 'meats for the belly and the belly for meats'?
options: God will destroy both it and them
They shall be offered as sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: God will destroy both it and them
questions.explanation: Paul explains the physical body's temporary nature contrasted with its purpose for the Lord; God will destroy both (1 Corinthians 6:13).

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 6:15, Paul warns against joining the members of Christ with what?
questions.explanation: Paul warns believers not to unite their bodies, members of Christ, with a harlot, emphasizing holiness (1 Corinthians 6:15).

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6:16 teach about the spiritual union between a man and a harlot?
questions.explanation: Paul explains that a man joined to a harlot becomes one body, referencing the biblical concept of 'one flesh' (1 Corinthians 6:16).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:18, what kind of sin is fornication categorized as?
options: A sin against one's own body
questions.correctAnswer: A sin against one's own body
questions.explanation: Paul states that fornication is a unique sin committed against one's own body, unlike other sins which are outside the body (1 Corinthians 6:18).

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 6:19 describes the believer's body as the temple of the Holy Ghost, which they possess as their own property.
questions.explanation: Paul declares that believers' bodies are temples of the Holy Ghost and that they are not their own, emphasizing God's ownership (1 Corinthians 6:19).

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:1, why is it inappropriate for believers to take disputes before unjust judges rather than the saints?
options: Because saints are appointed to judge the world
Because unjust judges have no wisdom
Because it damages the church’s reputation
questions.correctAnswer: Because saints are appointed to judge the world
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 6:1 emphasizes that believers should resolve disputes among themselves because the saints are appointed to judge the world, reflecting the authority given to the church as also seen in Daniel 7:22, John 5:22, 1 Peter 4:17, and Revelation 20:4.

questions.question: What future role of believers is highlighted in 1 Corinthians 6:2 that supports their ability to judge even small matters?
options: Believers will be kings over nations
Believers will be priests unto God
Believers will receive crowns of righteousness
questions.explanation: The verse states that saints shall judge the world, which implies their unworthiness to judge smaller matters is unfounded. This is supported by Romans 8:17, Revelation 2:26, 1 Peter 2:9, and Matthew 19:28 where believers share in Christ's authority to judge.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 6:3, it is stated believers will judge angels. What theological implication does this have regarding the believer’s status?
options: Believers participate in Christ’s authority over spiritual beings
Believers are superior to all earthly authorities
questions.correctAnswer: Believers participate in Christ’s authority over spiritual beings
questions.explanation: Judging angels indicates the believer's participation in Christ’s reign and authority over spiritual realms, consistent with Hebrews 2:5-8, Matthew 25:31-46, Jude 1:6, and Revelation 3:21.

questions.question: Which group does Paul suggest should judge disputes within the church according to 1 Corinthians 6:4?
options: Those least esteemed in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Those least esteemed in the church
questions.explanation: Paul advises that even those considered least esteemed should judge disputes, highlighting humility and responsibility within the body, paralleling Luke 22:26, James 2:1-4, Matthew 20:26-27, and Philippians 2:3.

questions.question: What issue does Paul address with 'I speak to your shame' in 1 Corinthians 6:5?
options: Lack of wise men to judge between brethren
questions.correctAnswer: Lack of wise men to judge between brethren
questions.explanation: Paul expresses shame that no wise person is found to settle disputes, emphasizing the need for spiritual maturity, as also taught in Proverbs 1:5, James 3:17, Titus 1:7-9, and Ecclesiastes 7:5.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:6, what inappropriate behavior is Paul rebuking among believers?
options: Brothers taking legal action against one another before unbelievers
Disputes causing division in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Brothers taking legal action against one another before unbelievers
questions.explanation: Paul condemns believers suing each other before secular courts, which exposes the church to unbelievers, contrary to Matthew 18:15-17, Romans 12:17-21, Exodus 23:1-3, and Psalm 82:3.

questions.question: What does Paul suggest believers should do rather than suing each other, according to 1 Corinthians 6:7?
options: Refuse to associate with the offender
questions.explanation: Paul encourages believers to endure wrong rather than litigate, demonstrating Christ-like humility and forgiveness, as taught in Matthew 5:39, 1 Peter 2:19, Romans 12:20, and Proverbs 20:22.

questions.question: Which of the following groups is NOT mentioned in 1 Corinthians 6:9-10 as unrighteous and excluded from the kingdom of God?
questions.explanation: Gluttons are not listed in this passage, while thieves, drunkards, and covetous persons are explicitly mentioned as unrighteous, supported by Galatians 5:19-21, Ephesians 5:5, Revelation 21:8, and Matthew 25:41.

questions.question: What transformation do believers experience according to 1 Corinthians 6:11?
options: Washed, sanctified, and justified in the name of the Lord Jesus and by the Spirit
Baptized, filled with the Spirit, and empowered for service
Cleansed by repentance and made holy by works
Adopted as sons and given spiritual gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Washed, sanctified, and justified in the name of the Lord Jesus and by the Spirit
questions.explanation: This verse describes the comprehensive salvation experience: cleansing, sanctification, and justification through Christ and the Spirit, consistent with Romans 5:1, Titus 3:5, Hebrews 10:10, and John 3:5.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 6:12 describe the believer's freedom under the law?
options: All things are lawful, but not all things are expedient
All things are forbidden except what is commanded
Freedom means doing whatever one desires without restraint
Law is abolished entirely for believers
questions.correctAnswer: All things are lawful, but not all things are expedient
questions.explanation: Paul teaches Christian liberty balanced with responsibility, echoing Galatians 5:13, Romans 6:12-14, 1 Peter 2:16, and James 1:25 about lawful freedom not leading to bondage or sin.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6:13 say about the body’s purpose in relation to fornication?
options: The body is not for fornication but for the Lord
The body is for pleasure and enjoyment
Fornication is acceptable if it is within marriage
The body is neutral regarding sin
questions.correctAnswer: The body is not for fornication but for the Lord
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes the sacredness of the body as belonging to the Lord, opposing fornication, consistent with Romans 6:13, 1 Thessalonians 4:3-5, Ephesians 5:3, and Hebrews 13:4.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:15, why is it wrong to unite the body with a harlot?
options: Because the body is a member of Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Because the body is a member of Christ
questions.explanation: The body belongs to Christ and should not be joined to sin, reflecting the unity believers have with Christ, supported by Romans 12:5, Ephesians 5:30, Colossians 1:22, and John 15:5.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 6:16 teach about the relationship between a man and a harlot?
options: They are bound by legal contract
questions.explanation: Paul cites the Genesis principle of two becoming one flesh in sexual union, highlighting the spiritual and physical unity, as also taught in Genesis 2:24, Matthew 19:5, Ephesians 5:31, and Hebrews 13:4.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 6:17, what is the nature of the union between a person and the Lord?
questions.explanation: The believer joined to the Lord is united spiritually as one spirit, reflecting intimate union with Christ, supported by John 6:56, Romans 8:9, Galatians 2:20, and Ephesians 4:4.

questions.question: What command concerning sin does Paul give in 1 Corinthians 6:18?
questions.explanation: Paul commands believers to actively flee sexual immorality, highlighting the serious nature of this sin, consistent with Hebrews 12:1, 2 Timothy 2:22, Ephesians 5:3, and Job 31:1.
